qas.question: Who did The Sun support in the 1984-85 Miners' strike?

answers.text: the police and the Thatcher government

qas.question: Who was president of the Miners' union?
What did a picture of Scargill have him appear to be doing?
How did The Sun feel about the American bombing of Libya in 1986?

context: The Sun, during the Miners' strike of 1984–85, supported <a0_0>the police and the Thatcher government<a0_0/> against the striking NUM miners, and in particular the union's president, <a1_0>Arthur Scargill<a1_0/>. On 23 May 1984, The Sun prepared a front page with the headline "Mine Führer" and a photograph of Scargill with his arm in the air, a pose which made him look as though he was <a2_0>giving a Nazi salute<a2_0/>. The print workers at The Sun refused to print it. The Sun <a3_0>strongly supported the April 1986 bombing<a3_0/> of Libya by the US, which was launched from British bases. Several civilians were killed during the bombing. Their leader was "Right Ron, Right Maggie". That year, Labour MP <a4_0>Clare Short<a4_0/> attempted in vain to persuade Parliament to outlaw the pictures on Page Three and gained opprobrium from the newspaper for her stand.
